statement:
Let $X$ be a normal irreducible variety. The singular set $S\subset X$
has codimension 2 or more.

Assume not. We may assume $X$ is affine, since codimension is local. Now
let ${\mathfrak{u}}$ be the ideal of functions vanishing on $S$. This is
an ideal of height 1, so the local ring of $Y$,
${\mathcal{O}}_S=A(X)_{{\mathfrak{u}}}$, where $A(X)$ is the affine ring
of $X$, is a 1-dimensional local ring, and integrally closed, since $X$
is normal. Any integrally closed 1-dimensional local domain is a DVR,
and thus regular. But $S$ is the singular set, so its local ring is not
regular, a contradiction.
names: normal irreducible varieties are nonsingular in codimension 1
